than seven years ago Uh those efforts
have yet to yield fruit And the reason
is that envoy is layer a layer 7 proxy
It is effectively the Swiss Army knife
of the network or the kitchen sink It is
the jack of all trades and it does
everything and it does everything really
wonderfully and really cool But that
means there are literally thousands or
ten thousands of SIS calls that are
involved in running an envoy proxy And
each of those SIS calls needs to be
ported when we go to a new operating
system And effectively what we found is
that that's simply not practical uh
we're not going to be able to port Envoy
to Windows and maintain a Linux envoy
and Windows Envoy side by side uh
without a small army of developers and
maybe even not with them Uh additionally
we do think that Ambient represents a
better user experience for the vast
majority of our users and we're going to

CIS calls that were necessary to point
uh to port Ambient Zunnel proxy onto
Windows while leaving the envoy code
running on Linux
If you're not familiar with ambient this
is what an ambient architecture on
Windows is going to look like Uh we've
divided the functionality of the ISTO
service mesh between layer 4 and layer 7
Remember that layer 7 is your Swiss Army
knife It does everything It's probably
what you need in many cases You want all
those fancy bells and whistles but it's
also very difficult to make it
portable Layer 4 on the other hand is
quite boring Its job is to secure your
traffic with certificates It's
connectionbased there's no request
semantics and so we're able to have a
very small rustbased codebase in the Z
tunnel that runs on every node and gives
you the security baseline that you need
across every part of your service mesh
and then we're able to add envoy proxies
running either onbox or offbox uh as
needed for your layer 7 Swiss Army knife
fantastic sort of operations So we're
not getting rid of envoy in any sense of
the word We're simply making it not
required that Envoy be colllocated with
your application in order to run a
service

So if you've been around Linux for a

Windows case uh everything's a service
It's a Windows service that kind of runs
um as a as a Damon on your system in
your OS and containers are no are no
exception to that Uh the main service
that's at play for Windows containers is
something called the host compute system
The host compute system is a service
that takes care of spinning up
containers uh as well as HyperV virtual
machines Um and
um the Kublet and the container runtime
call out to it whenever Kubernetes spins
up new pods in your system uh host
comput systems implemented via a JSON

for updates all sorts of different
things there are several resources um
that are present within host compute

with the sort of very advanced things

privileged operations and so only admin

implementation Um but like I said before
in Kubernetes host comput system is at
the core of container setup and
tearown There is a companion service
within Windows called the host network
uh host network service and this is
responsible for setting up and tearing
down networking for the containers So
host compute system spins up the new
actual process the compute that runs
your container and host network service
is going to create the network what we
call in Linux the network name space the
little isolated runtime that the that
the network uh executes within um has
the same JSON API as the host compute
system and uh similarly to how the
container runtime calls host compute
system the CNI uh executes the host
network service for creating a
um networking stack for the
pod/container Um there is a concept
called a network compartment that's
going to really be the analog to the

same way that Linux creates a network

creates a uh network compartment on
Windows Um that's like I said the the
